content: The text chunk "SECTION 1. URANIUM ENRICHMENT DECONTAMINATION AND DECOMMISSIONING FUND." is extracted from a larger context that is not provided. The Secretary of Energy can use collected amounts for specified purposes without further appropriation or fiscal year limitation starting in 1999 and 2008 under the Atomic Energy Act of 1954. The funds from the Atomic Energy Act of 1954 shall be allocated to decontamination and decommissioning programs at gaseous diffusion plants in Portsmouth, Ohio, Paducah, Kentucky, and Oak Ridge, Tennessee based on the total number of Separative Work Units processed at each site. The Secretary of Energy must report the allocation to Congress within 60 days of enactment. Upon notification of lease termination at the plants in Ohio or Kentucky, the Department of Energy must inform relevant parties. The Department of Energy must decide on the future of a leased facility within 60 days of termination, which includes options like leasing to a successor entity, government operation, standby operation, or closure. If the decision is to no longer operate the facility, a decontamination and decommissioning program must be initiated promptly, along with necessary environmental reviews as per the National Environmental Policy Act of 1969. The Secretary of Energy is required to report to Congress on these actions. The Secretary of Energy must report to Congress a decontamination and decommissioning program for the Portsmouth, Ohio and Paducah, Kentucky gaseous diffusion plants within 180 days of a decision to close all or part of one of the plants. SEC. 3. PORTSMOUTH AND PADUCAH OPERATIONS OFFICE. The Department of Energy is required to establish a Portsmouth and Paducah Operations Office by March 30, 2000, to manage environmental restoration, nuclear energy, and uranium enrichment programs at the sites. The office will have budget and contracting authority, oversee projects like depleted uranium conversion and decontamination, and conduct environmental and safety oversight. Additionally, a plan for establishing the office must be submitted within 60 days of the enactment of the Act. The plan for transferring functions from the Oak Ridge Operations Office to the Portsmouth and Paducah Operations Office includes personnel transfers, budget requirements, physical space needs, and funding sources. It also outlines the reporting relationships, legal counsel, and chief financial officer provisions. The President's Budget request for fiscal year 2001 onwards will include separate funding for the Portsmouth and Paducah Operations Office. SEC. 4. CLOSURE OF GASEOUS DIFFUSION PLANT. The Department of Energy aims to minimize social and economic impacts when closing gaseous diffusion plants in Ohio and Kentucky. Contracts for plant shutdown work must prioritize employees for available jobs based on seniority and qualifications. The Department of Energy requires contractors to provide training for incumbent employees, pay wages and benefits as per the Service Contract Act of 1965, comply with the workforce restructuring plan, and allows suits for violations to be brought in any district court of the United States.
